I doubt that the titanium grid fins are “much heavier” (on earth) than the old aluminum ones. The fins are larger, but titanium has lower density than aluminum, and I’d guess that the total weight (on earth) is about the same. Perhaps titanium fins slightly heavier.

But, c’mon, Tim. They deploy when the rocket is in a ballistic trajectory, which means that (while they are deploying), they weigh EXACTLY the same as the old aluminum ones:

They weigh ... zero pounds.

Note they will have slightly larger mass & polar moment of inertia, but these values are so low that the back torque on the extender motors is tiny.

The fact that they deploy more slowly has to be an engineering re-design decision, not due to the change in mass from the switch from aluminum to titanium.

A number of the satellite separations were out of view. Coming up to the final 10th satellite separation, the commentator noted it was out of view. I thought, well... what could indicate the inevitable separation of this final out-of-view satellite? Sure enough, a pinpoint of light (a star?) appeared in the middle of the screen. Bingo. SpaceX noted the separation and the pinpoint of light changed direction. The vehicle had experienced a momentum shift as the final 10th satellite pushed away from the spacecraft. https://youtu.be/VshdafZvwrg?t=5272

BTW, in mid-60s there was such a thing as a mid-air retrieval. It worked just fine on old-school spy satellites film recovery containers. Yet SpaceX fairing may be simply too big and heavy to be caught by a helicopter in the same manner.

Faring parachute flight….In skydiving, we plan to land at a specific landing area.  After we open our parachute, we fly to a spot upwind of the place we want to land.  The exact spot is based on the wind conditions.  We fly downwind, turn a 90, fly, turn a 90, and are on “final”.  The turn timing is adjusted on the fly to make a spot on landing.  I am not sure how Spacex is working this problem, but it would seem reasonable that the parachute can be steered just like skydiving parachutes.  As soon as the parachute opens, an ideal landing location for both the faring to steer to and a spot the boat can make it to should be predictable.  Along this line of thinking, the boat would just need to get to the landing spot and the parachute needs to steer to the pre-determined spot, basically landing on the boat/net.  I am sure it is easier with a human brain and eyes in the loop, but maybe they could pick a skydiver brain for how to program it.

Tim, a truly important health comment, from a career paramedic. This type of congestion indicates a serious health issue. Trust me, I know the anatomy and physiology of this from barotrauma training, and also because many of us NYC paramedics have such airway problems from 9/11 Ground Zero exposure.

You don’t need more fluids! Your upper airways are congested - fluids can only add to that, especially when horizontal. Since altitude and diving affect you so much, and from the trend of how you sound for the last few months (I have definitely noticed!) you have a serious sinus issue - the openings aren’t properly open. At the moment, you quite possibly have temporary sleep apnea, thus the inability to stay asleep, and the sleep you get not restful. This level of congestion affects the soft palate, which can positionally block breathing. See an ENT doctor! A big priority!
